reviewText:
Early Access Review

Its hard to harshly judge the game considering its in alpha, but I do have some concerns I want to express.

The menu UI is atrocious at best, it feels like a console menu or rather I am pertty sure it is one, you can't use your mouse to select anything. You are stuck using the arrow keys to navigate and the alt keys to select and go back. If these keys can be changed I would love to know how, because then I could change the controls on how to drive the cars. I don't have a gamepad or wheel (just a joystick) so I am left with using (for me atleast) strange driving controls to race which becomes a nuissance as time goes on.
The graphics are pretty good, but they are not well optimized. I can't hold that against them at all though because it is alpha.
Currently I can only find the default red racecraft car to use and I am not the biggest fan of its balancing (meaning its acceleration rate, top speed, downforce etc.) and am looking forward to increased customizability of the cars in the future.

The best part about this game and, to me at least, makes it stand out from other racing games is the track generation. The procederal engine works most of the time and creates tracks that have a similar flavor but have yet to seem repetetive.

Overall I'd say this game has a lot of potential to become one of the greats and I would recomend keeping an eye on it as it develops.
voteText: 16 of 18 people (89%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Certainly one to keep an eye on.

Bear in mind that, at time of writing, there's no multiplayer or online sharing of tracks, one car and no customisation, and so those looking for lots of gamemodes/content may want to hold off for a bit until we discover if the stuff that's yet to be added is any good.

That said, the procedural track generator means that the single player is enjoyable, mostly down to the large variety of tracks that the track generator can give you.

So put it on your wishlist for now until more stuff starts getting added in but, if the stuff to be added is anything like whats in the game at the moment, the £15 the devs are asking for seems more than reasonable

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Interesting premise, seems like some great tech behind it. Been following the development of Racecraft since it started, and got in on the closed beta early on.

Pros:
-Great track generation system, they may all look similar but the procedural nature keeps things fresh.
-Graphics seem pretty clean and slick.
-Download size is nice and small, which is a nice change for modern racing games.

Cons:
-Performance is pretty poor. My system can handle most games on medium-high with 60fps. With Racecraft I get 25fps in the menus, 10-15fps when on track
-Menu is absolute garbage. Reminds me of a console game ported to PC, circa 2005. Mouse is completely unusable and controls for navigating around are weird.
-Lack of vehicle choice. Yes I get it's early access alpha, but despite the screenshots showing multiple cars, you can only drive one red one.
-Painful car setup options. It's done whilst you're on track by pressing left alt, then tapping right alt to select the option, then holding right alt until your tweaks are just right. I've never seen such poorly implemented UI decisions.
-AI cars are very floaty, they tend to drift over the track and never really have any feeling of being out there with

TL;DR If you can buy it cheap, then get it, otherwise hold off on this one. It has a good concept but the execution at this stage of the early access is not enough to warrant a $19.99 price tag.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I got early access to this game and was playing it in closed Alpha Thank you for letting me participate, this Game has a lot of potential it looks super awesome the devs have been working on it for a while and even without the in menu Mouse Support I am loving it. I do not own a wheel but play it just fine on Xbox 360 controller. I have played a few hours and did a few videos on it while testing my new Gaming Rig because of the settings and rendering capabilities of the game. This is one of those games you want to get early on and play for hours. So far max settings is bringing 120 fps no screen tearing no lagging just perfect game play you can't ask for a better game than this.
don't just load the game up and play it for 5 minutes then do a review saying it's bad.
I will update this review as I go because I haven't played everything on the game because it was just released Today and some of the menu, Graphics and other things may have changed during the closed Alpha, get on it let's play. at the time the video was recorded I was using 2x Windforce GTX 770 4GB video cards (were not in SLI) and only 8GB of ram.
My computer specs
Intel Core i7-6700K 8M Skylake Quad-Core 4.0 GHz LGA 1151
ASRock Z170 Pro4 LGA 1151 Intel Z170
G.SKILL Ripjaws V Series 16GB (2 x 8GB) 288-Pin DDR4 SDRAM DDR4 3000
EVGA GTX 970 4GB Superclocked
Microsoft Windows 10 Pro 64-bit
I know most people don't have Gaming rigs like this and a lot of people may experience some problems but I also have 3 other computers an i5 3570K @4.4GHz which played the game like a Boss 2 GTX 660 in SLI 8GB DDR3 max settings 60 to 70 fps a 3770k @ 3.8 GHz 2 Windforce GTX 770 4GB in SLI 8GB DDR3 max settings 80 to 90 FPS and last  i5 6600K @ 3.9GHz Windforce GTX Extreme 970 16GB DDR4 Max settings 100 to 110 FPS
The game plays smooth on all settings and I have spent some time playing around with just about everything I haven't found an issue yet, I really want to keep playing just to see what else it has.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ENG:

As Victory: The Age of Racing game, this is a very good and functional racing car game in which the main focus is mostly a multiplayer game.

The game is visually like many other really beautiful and functional physics.

The game has excellent maneuverability and a lot of driving assistance also for novice players.

The interface is clear but, yet tricky to use, because it can not be used with the mouse.

In contrast to the Victory: The Age of Racing, this also offers finally a solo player. There is an almost endless range of different tracks that can be played at this time also one of the driver against the artificial intelligence. Formula selection of cars is not like the one available at the moment.

However, this is becoming a very promising and effective basic formula car game, a testimonial!



FIN:

Kuten Victory: The Age of Racing peli, tämä on varsin hyvä ja toimiva kilpa-auto peli, jonka pääpaino on lähinnä moninpelissä.

Peli on visuaalisesti kuten monet muutkin todella kaunis ja fysiikalta toimiva.

Pelissä on erinomainen ajettavuus ja paljon ajoa avustavia apuja myös aloitteleville pelaajille.

Käyttöliittymä on selkeä mutta, hankala vielä käyttää, koska sitä ei voi käyttää hiirellä.

Toisin kuin Victory: The Age of Racing, tämä tarjoaa vihdoinkin myös jotakin yksin pelaajalle. Tarjolla on lähes loputtomasti erillaisia ratoja joita voi pelata tällä hetkellä myös yhtä tekoäly ajajaa vastaan. Formula auto valikoimaa ei ole kuin yksi tarjolla tällä hetkellä.

Tästä on kuitenkin tulossa varsin lupaava ja toimivan perus formula autopeli, suositteluni!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Yes, this game is a bit rough around the edges.
Yes, I don't particularly like Vae Victis.
And, yes, if they do this game right, can change my opinion on this game.

Don't get me wrong, this game still needs a hell of a lot of work before it is deemed play-able by the public. So far now, now that I got it finally working on my computer, it isn't half bad.

However, one gripe I have with this game is optimization. I'm running it on my 3 year old potato laptop, and I had to put all settings on low at 720p. Maybe I just need to get my gaming rig completed.

Track randomization is not bad at all. There was the occasional expirience where the track didn't load right, and left holes in the map and walls on the track itself blocking me from completing a lap. I would like to see options and sliders for track randomization, like complexity, length, height changes, and other variables.

Car handling is not that bad, altough it does need some touch-ups before launch.

All in all, not bad in Early Development, it just needs a bit more work done to it to make it able to play it for the consumer. And for the love of everyone around here, add AI racing. I've delt with Victory and not being able to play with other racers. Keep this game from becoming a ghost town with optional AI racing locally.

7/10 Great concept, great layout, needs some polish.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

4 March - Quick day-one review.
- It's Early Access, so it's obviously missing features, but i'm sure you won't regret: stable client, fresh graphics, smooth animations, good sounds, high quality overall, and lots of fun of course... can't wait for the cool features.

7 April
- They added the first PvP mode as weekly Events. In this competitive mode you race against the best player ghosts of the leaderboard. The track is randomly generated, and the top ghosts are automatically refreshed in real time, even during your lap.

26 May
- Car Paint mode added. You are free to choose patterns, three colors (on a total of 115, plus Metalness and Roughness effects), three sponsors, and your car number.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review is as of Early Access on March 4, 2016. I will modify and/or delete this review as the game updates and most likely delete it when the game fully launches to give it a fresh review.

---------

We need to start this off with a warning. The developers of Racecraft, Vae Victus, have only done one other Steam game, Victory: The Age of Racing. They abandoned the game for two years, then made it free-to-play and have still yet to update it in any way. This studio's track record is small but horrible, so please bear that in mind.

Racecraft is designed to be a procedurally-generated driving game, its gameplay being based in simulation with some arcade modifications to it. It was a formula that worked fairly well in Victory, and it's been refined here in Racecraft. Driving feels tight yet fluid enough so that it doesn't feel stiff, and the sense of speed is there. When it comes down to the core gameplay, Racecraft has got many of the checkboxes marked. My biggest concern with one of the previous versions in the closed Alpha was that there were a lot of symbols and signs on the track that I couldn't identify. My racing history is mostly in Need for Speed - I'm not a racing sim gamer - so it would have been helpful to have some explanation on what the track signs meant.

Outside of gameplay, Racecraft falls short of being a stable game to play in. Again, keep in mind that this is still Early Access, so things are bound to be, well, Early Access. But there's a myriad of issues present in the current version. 1) The game just crashed on me while I was preparing to write this review. 2) The menus are extremely slow to respond, slow to animate, and do not have mouse control (as a game releasing on Steam in 2016, that last part shouldn't even be there). 3) The game's menus are locked behind the procedural track generator, so you'll be waiting a while before you can even change the game from fullscreen or turning off its effects or what have you. 4) Gameplay itself is incredibly sluggish, even when I turn off all effects, get out of fullscreen, and lower the resolution.

There also seems to be some sort of issue with controller support. Sometimes it recognizes my Logitech Wireless Gamepad F710, sometimes it doesn't. For the record, Racecraft will fully support wheels (if it doesn't already), so if you have one of those peripherals you're in luck here. It should also be stated that Racecraft requires DirectX 11 or newer, so if you're running DirectX 10 or older (which millions of Steam accounts still are), you won't be able to play Racecraft.

Because of the many issues with the game, I cannot recommend Racecraft in its current state. I look forward to future updates, and as I stated in my disclaimer I will update this review as such, but for now I advise staying away.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is my first review after one race.

i am a big fan of LFS - life for speed. This game has been my favourite racing simulation for years.
Comparing Racecraft to LFS, Racecraft needs the following improvements:

- setup of the car should be changeable
- sound of the car can be improved to be more realistic
- a serious damage model needs to be implemented
- single player with more opponents
- multiplayer with some sort of leaderboard or similar.

But this are things that still ned to be implemented.

Now I come to the apparent pros and cons of the game

+ relatively easy to drive the car
+ till now i could not detect any lagging - even with fullest graphics settings (on a GeForce GTX 970)
-  car tends to drift a lot - but with a realistic setup of the car this could be minimized
-  controller setup needs to be redone. my logitech gamepad was regognized but i couldnt calibrate it.
+ game didnt crash in the first run.


Improvements that should be done to the unique gameplay:

-the race track generator should be customizable (e.g. length of straights, number of turns, sharpness of turns,
elevations and so on)
- Better calibration of the game controllers and even the keyboard calibration could be tweaked a bit
- Mouse control in the menues is essential.

in the current early access state of the game i would give 4 of 10 points.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early Access Review. Thanks for adding gamepad support, now the game is playable. :)

Pros+
Randomly Generate Tracks
Gamepad Support(Now)
Simple Menu/GUI
Easy Control
Performance for Early Access isn't too bad. Recording it drops down to 25-35fps. Not recording i get 39-60fps, at 1600x900 high with AA.

Cons-
I know its early access, but most of the other visual options are disable.
Tracks are bland and boring looking.
On that note, the graphics doesn't look at that good right now.
Some random tracks are not completed and have invisible walls
Some graphic errors
Game feels a bit too early like 30% completed.

Bottom line. I do recommend this game, but only for 4.99. The game is great and fun to play now that it has more camera views and gamepad support. But its in early access and it only feels about 30% completed, 15 bucks is way too steep. Besides that, i also find it odd that they didn't just upgrade / update Victory: Age of Racing with a new patch like 6GB of new content, new tracks, DX11, more modes, cars, etc. I think that would of been a better choice then making a new game, but whatever both are fun.

Early Access Score: 6/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL/DR  deja-vu?

Great idea, procedural tracks, early days so a bit rough round the edges.  Updated review since latest game updates.

The game itself is similar to Victory and the track generator made it in this time. The procedural tracks it makes are surprisingly good. There is some nice tech there.  So they are off to a good start with this one.

The potential is there for an outstanding game if the developers carry it through this time.

So I'd leave it a while and see how it develops, or buy it if you are happy taking a risk on an Early Access getting finished and delivering as promised.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So another update to the game. This one adds some more cars on the track. Well not a lot more but more then just 1 other car. Now the game has events. They last for 6 days. Best time wins. You race at first against what I think is the best timed driver then after your first lap you have another ghost car that includes your previous lap. It has the same track thru the 6 day tourney. So now your racing against your ghost and the fastest ghost time. It does make the game a lot more interesting to play around with. So at least now their is a reason to drive fast around the track. I still am not a big fan of this racer yet. Their is still not enough meat on the bone so to speak for the price. The lap for the event can be completed in around a minute or so. So racing around the track for around 4 to 5 times to get a good lap time. Perhaps longer. However after thats done their isnt much to do with the game at this point.



So the game got an update. The game does a look a little better.


So its a very rough game at the moment. The car doesnt look all that great.  Its strange. The sound is sparse. You hear your car and thats about it.

The track generator is a mixed bag. The problem I have with it right now are the jumps that they include in the track. Now for a game that has F1 looking cars why include a jump?? I was leading the race playing against the 1 Ai that you cannot touch nor can he touch you. When blam I hit a cliff and it sends my car spinning end over end. Jumps do not belong in this game and I hope they take them out. Its crazy to have a jump with an F1 car. The track them selves are kind of boring. Nothing moves and their is no crowd. So its you racing against another car and generated tracks.

Also the game has strange warning markers? I do understand the markers now. 1 is an extreme turn and higher means a less extreme turn.

Thats about the whole entire game.  I think if someone expected a full racing experience they are going to be sadly disapointed. The game that is here is extremely thin. Race against one  AI driver or race a hotlap. I also think the asking price is way way to high at the moment. $16 dollars for a bare bones racer. Also just a slight annoyance in the preview its a lot misleading. I was racing against one ai racer and I did not find any options for other race cars to be on the track. The options were hot laps or race against the AI. To my way of thinking those pictures showing other cars (they showed 4 other cars on the track)  is make believe and very wrong. In the future yeah then  maybe other 3 or more cars on the track but for now its just one ai racer.

At the moment I cannot really recommend this game right now. Its way to much of a bare bones racer. To me the starting price should have been around $10 dollars. Then after they added features the price could have gone up by double. Your much better with Burnout Paradise or the trackmania game series. Same price but much more content.  If I am wrong on the amount of cars on the track then leave me a note stating how I can have more then just the one ai racer on the track.

I realize the review is long however I wanted to give an accurate review. So in the future I may change my review to be more positive.  However its just so thin I would not recommend this game at this time. Like I said I may change my review later on as the game gets updates.
